## Part 1: Reading in data

There are two data files you need for this assignment:

-   `tpl_branch_general_info_2023.csv`

-   `tpl_branch_workstation_usage_2018-2023.csv`

They are both located under `r/05_src/assignment-2-data`. Write R code to read these files.

```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(here)

branch_info <- read_csv(here("05_src/assignment-2-data/tpl_branch_general_info_2023.csv")) # Your code here
  
branch_workstation_usage <- read_csv(here("05_src/assignment-2-data/tpl_branch_workstation_usage_2018-2023.csv")) # Your code here
```

## Part 2: Wrangling data

Before we are able to draw conclusions from the data, make the following modifications to the data:

-   The branch general information dataset contains virtual library services. **Drop these rows and keep only physical library locations.**

-   **Join the two datasets** so that all the information is in a single dataframe.

```{r}
# Your code below

# see column names
colnames(branch_info)

# see what the PhysicalBranch column looks like
branch_info |> 
  select(PhysicalBranch) |>
  head()

physical_branch_info <- branch_info |>
  filter(PhysicalBranch == 1)

full_data <- left_join(physical_branch_info, branch_workstation_usage, by = "BranchCode")
```

## Part 3: The largest and busiest branches

Which library branches...

1.  ... the most workstations available?
2.  ... the highest numbers of workstation usage sessions?
3.  ... the most usage sessions per workstation?

Write R code to show the names of the top 5 library branches for each question. Print only the names of the branches.

**Hint**: `head(my_data, 5)` will return the first 5 rows of the dataframe `my_data`.

```{r}
# Your code below

# 1. Branches with the most workstations available:
physical_branch_info |>
  arrange(desc(Workstations)) |>
  select(BranchName, Workstations) |> 
  head(5)

# 2. Branches with the highest numbers of workstation usage sessions
full_data |>
  group_by(BranchName) |>
  summarise(total_sessions = sum(Sessions)) |> 
  arrange(desc(total_sessions)) |>
  head(5)

# 3. Branches with highest numbers of sessions per workstation
totals <- branch_workstation_usage |>
  group_by(BranchCode) |>
  summarise(total_sessions = sum(Sessions))

left_join(physical_branch_info, totals, by = "BranchCode") |>
  mutate(sessions_per_workstation = total_sessions/Workstations) |>
  arrange(desc(sessions_per_workstation)) |>
  select(BranchName, sessions_per_workstation) |>
  head(5)

```

## Part 4: Library usage over the years

How has library workstation usage changed between 2018-2023? Use ggplot to chart the number of workstation sessions annually at the Toronto Reference Library and North York Central Library branches during these years.

```{r}
# Your code below
full_data |>
  filter(BranchName == "Toronto Reference Library" | BranchName == "North York Central Library") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = Sessions)) +
    geom_line(aes(colour = BranchName))
```
